results.title: Don't throw the bat
results.brief_description: A knock on the head with a baseball bat, sends the first batter off for an injection but running a marathon may be preferable to getting a jab in the arm.

results.title: Don't tell me I'll find out (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles and John Quick
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Science Curriculum Improvement Studies”.
Organisms: includes first grade children observing aquaria and seed planting. Lifecycles: second graders plant and observe growth of beans, also observe fruitfly in pupae and adult stages. Populations: third grade children observe crickets eating clover and chameleons eating crickets, introducing the terms predator and prey.

results.title: Don't start off with an accident
results.creator_credit: Perier Films, New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry, Reg Perier and Stan Murdoch
results.brief_description: Starts with a young recruit to a production factory who has a minor accident with equipment. Shows the many dangers with improper equipment handling and the importance of safety training. Expands to cover safety aspects of other industries, particularly building.

results.title: Don't stand so close to me
results.brief_description: On the threshold of year 12 Morgan Preston seems to have everything under control. She has a best friend, is familiar with the teachers, and is keeping on top of the ever increasing amount of homework. Morgan’s stability is threatened with the arrival of a new history teacher, Jack Hamilton. Jack and Morgan develop an unusual relationship that challenges the boundaries of conformity and forces both of them into a moral dilemma. Cast includes Alison Gordon, Luke Dean, Georgina McClure and Maureen Sherlock.

results.title: Don't shoot the writer
results.brief_description: An excellent documentary on the evolution of the Australian film and television industry. By interviewing screenwriters such as David Williamson, Eleanor Whitcombe (My Brilliant Career) and Roger Simpson (Sword of Honour) we are given an insight into the struggles in the late 60’s and 70’s to develop an Australian film culture; on the formation of the Australian Writers Guild to help encourage writing for the screen; and the struggle to see their visions realised on television and the cinema.

results.title: Don't send your daughter
results.creator_credit: Audio-Visual Aids, University of Melbourne and Robin Roger Cook
results.brief_description: Produced for the Students Representative Council, University of Melbourne, this film summarises the first year of life at the University. It shows new students at the “freshers” camp at Anglesea; the main sections of the University; view of the library and instructions how to use it; scenes at the Cabaret Ball; an Engineering School lecture; sports activities; graduating ceremony; exams.

results.title: Don't push your luck
results.brief_description: A dramatic eye safety film featuring Bill Frank of Chicago, Illinois, a genuine eye accident casualty who re-enacts the events before and after his injury. A variety of typical work situations where eye injuries can occur are shown and impact tests are used to recommend the use of protective eyewear. Some members of the Wise Owls Club show the effectiveness of safety glass in preventing injury.

results.title: Don't move = Non ti muovere
results.creator_credit: Cattleya, Medusa Film, Marco Chimenz, Giovanni Stabilini, Riccardo Tozzi and Sergio Castellitto
results.brief_description: As his teenage daughter’s life hangs in the balance, a surgeon recalls crucial moments of his life, including an angst-ridden affair with a marginalised Albanian woman (a seriously de-glamorised Penelope Cruz) who he raped, but subsequently became sexually and emotionally entangled with. Adapted from the best-selling novel by Margaret Mazzantini, Castellitto (who also wrote the screenplay and previously directed the charming drama “Mostly Martha”) presents an unflattering view of male anguish, betrayal and brutality as Timoteo becomes conflicted by his double life as an urbane husband on the one hand and a violent lover to a troubled waif, living in abject conditions, on the other.

results.title: Don't mess with Bill
results.brief_description: This documentary focuses on Bill Underwood, an 84 year old Canadian who has developed his own brand of self defence known as ‘defendo’ which he teaches to police groups, college students and senior citizens. Bill’s contagious energy and enthusiasm isn’t limited to self defence, he freely discusses his positive attitude to life which seems to be responsible for his good health and general wellbeing.
